title: Sharing is Caring
story: Bunny was playing with their favorite red ball in the park. Along came Fox, who wanted to play with the ball too. Bunny felt sad because they didn't want to share their special ball. What should Bunny do?
imagePrompt: A cute bunny holding a red ball, with a friendly fox nearby in a sunny park

choices.text: Share the ball and take turns playing
choices.explanation: Great choice! Sharing helps us make friends and have more fun together. When we share, everyone feels happy!

choices.text: Run away with the ball
choices.explanation: Running away might make Fox feel sad. Let's think about how we can both have fun together!

choices.text: Say 'maybe later' and keep playing alone
choices.explanation: It's okay to want to play alone sometimes, but sharing can make playtime even more fun! Maybe you could play together for a little while?

choices.text: Ask Fox to bring their own ball
choices.explanation: That's a creative idea! But right now, Fox wants to play with you. Sharing your ball could be a great way to make a new friend!

endingMessage: You did a wonderful job thinking about sharing! When we share our toys, we make friends and create happy memories together. Remember, sharing makes playtime more fun for everyone! üåü

title: Dark Night, Bright Heart
story: It was bedtime and Bear's room was very dark. Bear felt scared because they couldn't see anything. The shadows on the wall looked like scary monsters. What should Bear do?
imagePrompt: A small bear in a cozy bedroom at night, with soft shadows and a nightlight nearby

choices.text: Ask a grown-up for a nightlight or to leave the door open
choices.explanation: Excellent idea! Asking for help when we're scared is very brave. A nightlight or open door can make the dark feel safer!

choices.text: Stay awake all night
choices.explanation: Staying awake all night would make Bear very tired. It's better to find a way to feel safe so we can rest!

choices.text: Hide under the covers
choices.explanation: Hiding can feel safe for a moment, but talking to a grown-up about our fears helps us feel better for the whole night!

choices.text: Pretend to be asleep
choices.explanation: Pretending won't make the scary feelings go away. It's better to tell someone how we feel so they can help us!

endingMessage: You're so brave! It's okay to feel scared sometimes. Talking to grown-ups about our fears helps us find ways to feel safe and peaceful. Sweet dreams! üåô

title: Where Did It Go?
story: Puppy couldn't find their favorite stuffed animal, Mr. Snuggles. They looked in their room, the living room, and even the backyard, but Mr. Snuggles was nowhere to be found. Puppy felt worried and sad. What should Puppy do?
imagePrompt: A worried puppy looking around a messy room, searching for a lost stuffed animal

choices.text: Ask a grown-up to help search and check the last place they remember having it
choices.explanation: Great thinking! Asking for help and retracing our steps is the best way to find lost things. Grown-ups can help us look in places we might forget!

choices.text: Cry and give up looking
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel sad, but giving up means we might never find Mr. Snuggles! Let's try asking for help instead!

choices.text: Keep looking alone in the same places
choices.explanation: It's good to keep trying! But sometimes asking for help or thinking about new places to look can help us find things faster!

choices.text: Buy a new toy instead
choices.explanation: A new toy might be fun, but Mr. Snuggles is special! Let's try to find the original one first - it might be in a surprising place!

endingMessage: You showed great problem-solving skills! When we lose something important, asking for help and thinking carefully about where we last saw it can help us find it. Don't give up! üîç

title: Time for Bed
story: Kitten had been playing all day and now it was bedtime. Kitten felt very tired but didn't want to stop playing. They wanted to stay up and have more fun. What should Kitten do?
imagePrompt: A sleepy kitten yawning, with toys scattered around and a cozy bed in the background

choices.text: Follow the bedtime routine: brush teeth, put on pajamas, read a story, then sleep
choices.explanation: Perfect! Following a bedtime routine helps our bodies and minds get ready for sleep. We'll have more energy for fun tomorrow!

choices.text: Keep playing until they fall asleep on the floor
choices.explanation: Sleeping on the floor isn't as comfortable as a bed! A good bedtime routine helps us sleep better and feel rested!

choices.text: Ask to stay up just 10 more minutes
choices.explanation: It's okay to ask, but our bodies need rest to grow and stay healthy. A good night's sleep helps us have more fun tomorrow!

choices.text: Hide so no one can find them
choices.explanation: Hiding won't help us feel less tired! It's better to talk about our feelings and follow our bedtime routine together!

endingMessage: You made a smart choice! Sleep is important for growing bodies and happy days. When we get good rest, we wake up ready for new adventures! Good night! üåô

title: First Day Adventure
story: Duckling was starting at a new school tomorrow. They had never been to school before and didn't know anyone. Duckling felt nervous about meeting new friends and learning new things. What should Duckling do?
imagePrompt: A small duckling looking at a school building, feeling nervous but curious

choices.text: Talk to a grown-up about feelings, pack a favorite toy, and remember that everyone feels nervous on the first day
choices.explanation: Wonderful! Talking about our feelings and bringing something familiar can help us feel braver. Remember, everyone feels nervous on the first day - you're not alone!

choices.text: Pretend to be sick so they don't have to go
choices.explanation: Pretending to be sick won't make the nervous feelings go away. It's better to talk about how we feel and find ways to feel braver!

choices.text: Stay quiet and hope no one notices them
choices.explanation: It's okay to be quiet, but school is a place to make friends and learn! Maybe you could try saying hello to one person - they might be nervous too!

choices.text: Bring lots of toys to share
choices.explanation: Sharing is nice, but the most important thing is to be yourself and be kind. Your new friends will like you for who you are!

endingMessage: You're so brave! Starting something new can feel scary, but it's also exciting! Remember, everyone at school is learning and making friends too. You've got this! üéí

title: Playground Pals
story: Squirrel was at the playground and saw other animals playing together. Squirrel wanted to join them but felt shy and didn't know how to ask. Squirrel felt lonely watching everyone else have fun. What should Squirrel do?
imagePrompt: A squirrel watching other animals play together on a playground, looking shy and hopeful

choices.text: Walk over, smile, and say 'Can I play too?'
choices.explanation: Excellent! Being friendly and asking to join is the best way to make new friends. Most kids love when others want to play with them!

choices.text: Go home because no one wants to play with them
choices.explanation: Don't give up! The other animals probably don't know you want to play. Asking them is the first step to making friends!

choices.text: Wait and hope someone invites them
choices.explanation: Waiting is okay, but sometimes we need to be brave and ask! Most kids are happy to include new friends in their games!

choices.text: Play alone and ignore everyone
choices.explanation: Playing alone can be fun, but if you want to play with others, it's better to ask! You might be surprised how welcoming they are!

endingMessage: You showed great courage! Making friends can feel scary, but being friendly and asking to join in is how friendships begin. You're a wonderful friend! üéà

title: Test Day Jitters
story: Owl had a big math test tomorrow. They studied hard but still felt worried about forgetting everything. Owl's tummy felt funny and they couldn't sleep. What should Owl do?
imagePrompt: An owl with books and papers, looking worried about an upcoming test

choices.text: Take deep breaths, review notes one more time, get good sleep, and remember they prepared well
choices.explanation: Perfect! Deep breathing helps calm our bodies, and getting rest helps our brains work better. You've prepared - trust yourself!

choices.text: Stay up all night studying more
choices.explanation: Staying up all night makes us too tired to think clearly! Sleep is important for remembering what we learned!

choices.text: Worry about it all night
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel worried, but worrying won't help us do better. Let's try some calming strategies instead!

choices.text: Pretend to be sick to skip the test
choices.explanation: Avoiding the test won't make the worry go away - it will just come back later. It's better to face our fears with good preparation!

endingMessage: You handled that so well! Feeling nervous about tests is normal, and you found healthy ways to cope. Remember, doing your best is what matters most! üìö

title: Left Out
story: Rabbit's best friend Fox was having a birthday party and invited everyone in class except Rabbit. Rabbit felt hurt and confused about why they weren't invited. What should Rabbit do?
imagePrompt: A rabbit looking sad, seeing other animals excited about a party invitation

choices.text: Talk to Fox privately about feelings, ask if there's a reason, and suggest doing something fun together another time
choices.explanation: Great communication! Talking about our feelings in a calm way helps us understand what happened and work through it together!

choices.text: Get angry and stop being friends with Fox
choices.explanation: Getting angry right away might make things worse. It's better to talk about our feelings first and understand what happened!

choices.text: Pretend it doesn't matter and ignore Fox
choices.explanation: It's okay to protect our feelings, but talking about what happened can help us understand and maybe fix the friendship!

choices.text: Have their own party and not invite Fox
choices.explanation: Trying to get back at someone usually makes things worse. It's better to talk about our feelings and try to understand what happened!

endingMessage: You showed emotional maturity! Talking about our feelings when we're hurt is brave and helps us work through problems. Friendships can have bumps, but communication helps! üíô

title: Too Much to Do
story: Beaver had lots of homework: math problems, a book report, and a science project. It all seemed like too much to finish. Beaver felt overwhelmed and didn't know where to start. What should Beaver do?
imagePrompt: A beaver surrounded by books and papers, looking overwhelmed by too much homework

choices.text: Break it into small steps, start with the easiest task, take breaks, and ask for help if needed
choices.explanation: Excellent strategy! Breaking big tasks into smaller pieces makes them feel less scary. Starting with something easy builds confidence!

choices.text: Try to do everything at once
choices.explanation: Doing everything at once can make us feel more overwhelmed! It's better to take things one step at a time!

choices.text: Put it off until the last minute
choices.explanation: Putting things off usually makes us feel more stressed later. Starting early, even with small steps, helps us feel better!

choices.text: Just don't do any of it
choices.explanation: Not doing homework might feel easier now, but it will cause problems later. Let's find a way to make it manageable!

endingMessage: You found a great solution! When things feel too big, breaking them into smaller pieces helps us feel capable and successful. You've got this! üìù

title: Sibling Squabble
story: Chipmunk's little sibling kept interrupting while they were trying to do homework. The sibling wanted to play and wouldn't leave Chipmunk alone. Chipmunk felt frustrated and angry. What should Chipmunk do?
imagePrompt: A chipmunk trying to work while a smaller chipmunk tries to get attention

choices.text: Calmly explain they need quiet time, suggest playing together later, and ask a grown-up for help if needed
choices.explanation: Perfect! Using calm words and setting boundaries helps. Suggesting time together later shows you care about your sibling too!

choices.text: Yell and push the sibling away
choices.explanation: Yelling and pushing can hurt feelings and make things worse. Let's try using calm words instead!

choices.text: Ignore them and hope they go away
choices.explanation: Ignoring might work sometimes, but talking calmly about what you need usually works better and keeps everyone happy!

choices.text: Lock themselves in their room
choices.explanation: Locking doors can be unsafe and doesn't solve the problem. It's better to talk about boundaries with a grown-up's help!

endingMessage: You handled that conflict so well! Setting boundaries calmly and suggesting time together later shows maturity. Siblings can be tricky, but communication helps! üë´

title: Standing Out
story: Penguin loved reading books while all their friends loved playing sports. Sometimes Penguin felt like they didn't fit in because their interests were different. What should Penguin do?
imagePrompt: A penguin reading a book while other animals play sports in the background

choices.text: Embrace their unique interests, find friends who share similar hobbies, and remember that being different is special
choices.explanation: Wonderful! Being different makes you special! It's great to have your own interests, and you can find friends who appreciate what makes you unique!

choices.text: Pretend to like sports just to fit in
choices.explanation: Pretending to be someone else won't make you happy. Being true to yourself helps you find real friends who like you for who you are!

choices.text: Stop reading and only do what friends do
choices.explanation: It's okay to try new things, but you don't have to give up what you love! You can enjoy both your interests and your friends' activities!

choices.text: Avoid all friends completely
choices.explanation: Avoiding friends won't help! You can have your own interests AND be friends with people who have different interests. That's what makes friendships interesting!

endingMessage: You're amazing just as you are! Having different interests makes you unique and interesting. True friends will like you for who you are! üåü

title: Not First This Time
story: Cheetah loved running races and usually won. Today, they came in third place. Cheetah felt disappointed and sad. They thought about giving up running altogether. What should Cheetah do?
imagePrompt: A cheetah looking disappointed after a race, standing on a third-place podium

choices.text: Feel the disappointment, congratulate the winners, practice more, and remember that everyone has off days
choices.explanation: Excellent attitude! It's okay to feel disappointed, but being a good sport and learning from the experience makes you a true champion!

choices.text: Quit running forever
choices.explanation: One race doesn't define you! Everyone has days when things don't go perfectly. Giving up means missing out on future successes!

choices.text: Blame the other runners for winning
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel frustrated, but blaming others won't help us improve. Let's focus on what we can learn and control!

choices.text: Pretend they don't care about running
choices.explanation: Pretending we don't care about something we love won't make us feel better. It's okay to be disappointed and still keep trying!

endingMessage: You showed great sportsmanship! Feeling disappointed is normal, but learning from setbacks and being a good sport makes you a true winner. Keep going! üèÉ

title: Following the Pack
story: Wolf's friends wanted to skip class and go to the park instead. Wolf knew it was wrong but didn't want to be left out or seem uncool. Wolf felt pressured to go along. What should Wolf do?
imagePrompt: A wolf looking conflicted, with friends in the background encouraging them to skip class

choices.text: Politely decline, suggest doing something fun after school instead, and stick to their values
choices.explanation: Excellent decision! Standing up for what you believe in takes courage. True friends will respect your choices, and you can still have fun together in better ways!

choices.text: Go along even though it feels wrong
choices.explanation: Going against our values usually makes us feel worse, not better. It's better to be true to ourselves and find friends who respect our choices!

choices.text: Go but feel guilty about it
choices.explanation: That guilty feeling is telling us something important! When something doesn't feel right, it's usually because it isn't. Trust your instincts!

choices.text: Tell on the friends to get them in trouble
choices.explanation: Tattling to get others in trouble isn't the best approach. It's better to make your own good choice and let others make theirs!

endingMessage: You showed incredible strength! Standing up for your values, even when it's hard, shows true character. You can be a leader by making good choices! üí™

title: New Wings
story: Butterfly used to love dance class, but lately they've been more interested in art. Their dance friends seemed disappointed, and Butterfly felt confused about changing interests. What should Butterfly do?
imagePrompt: A butterfly looking at art supplies while dance shoes sit in the background

choices.text: Talk to friends about the change, explore new interests while keeping old friendships, and remember it's okay to grow and change
choices.explanation: Perfect! It's completely normal for interests to change as we grow. Good friends will support you exploring new things while staying friends!

choices.text: Keep doing dance even though they don't enjoy it anymore
choices.explanation: Doing something you don't enjoy just to please others won't make you happy. It's okay to explore new interests - that's how we grow!

choices.text: Feel guilty about changing
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel a little guilty, but changing interests is a natural part of growing up! You can still be friends with people who have different interests!

choices.text: Stop being friends with dance friends
choices.explanation: You don't have to stop being friends just because your interests changed! Good friendships can include people with different hobbies!

endingMessage: You're growing and discovering who you are! Changing interests is a natural part of growing up. True friends will support you exploring new passions! üé®

title: Growing Apart
story: Dolphin and their best friend Seal had been close for years, but lately they seemed to be growing apart. They had different interests and didn't hang out as much. Dolphin felt sad about the friendship changing. What should Dolphin do?
imagePrompt: Two dolphins swimming in different directions, looking a bit sad

choices.text: Talk openly about the changes, try new activities together, and accept that friendships can evolve while still being meaningful
choices.explanation: Wonderful approach! Friendships do change as we grow, and that's okay. Talking about it and trying new things together can help keep the friendship strong!

choices.text: Get angry and end the friendship completely
choices.explanation: Ending a friendship because it's changing might make us feel worse. It's better to talk about what's happening and see if you can grow together!

choices.text: Pretend everything is the same
choices.explanation: Pretending won't make the changes go away. It's better to acknowledge what's happening and work together to adapt the friendship!

choices.text: Try to force Seal to like the same things
choices.explanation: Trying to change someone else won't work and might push them away. It's better to find new ways to connect that work for both of you!

endingMessage: You handled that with maturity! Friendships do change as we grow, and that's normal. Sometimes friendships evolve, and sometimes we find new ways to stay connected. You're learning important life skills! üíô

title: New Heights
story: Eagle was starting middle school next year. They worried about harder classes, making new friends, getting lost in a bigger school, and having multiple teachers. Eagle felt anxious about all the changes. What should Eagle do?
imagePrompt: An eagle looking at a large school building, feeling nervous about the transition

choices.text: Talk to current teachers, visit the school, connect with other students going there, and remember that everyone feels nervous about transitions
choices.explanation: Excellent preparation! Learning about what to expect and connecting with others helps reduce anxiety. Remember, everyone starting middle school feels nervous - you're not alone!

choices.text: Worry constantly and lose sleep
choices.explanation: Worrying won't help us prepare! It's better to take action - learn about the school, talk to people, and get ready in positive ways!

choices.text: Pretend they're not worried at all
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel worried - that's normal! Acknowledging our feelings and preparing for the change helps us feel more confident!

choices.text: Try to stay in elementary school forever
choices.explanation: We can't avoid growing up, but we can prepare for it! Learning about middle school and getting ready helps us feel more confident about the change!

endingMessage: You're preparing so well! Transitions can feel scary, but you're taking positive steps to get ready. Middle school is a new adventure, and you've got the skills to handle it! üéì

title: Measuring Up
story: Lion worked hard on a science project and got a B+. Their friend got an A+ on the same project. Lion felt like they weren't good enough and compared themselves to their friend. What should Lion do?
imagePrompt: A lion looking at their B+ grade while seeing a friend's A+ grade, feeling disappointed

choices.text: Focus on their own progress, celebrate the B+ as good work, learn from what went well, and remember that everyone has different strengths
choices.explanation: Perfect mindset! Comparing ourselves to others usually makes us feel worse. Focusing on our own growth and celebrating our achievements is much healthier!

choices.text: Feel like a failure and give up on science
choices.explanation: A B+ is good work! One grade doesn't define you. Giving up because someone else did better won't help you grow and learn!

choices.text: Try to copy exactly what the friend did next time
choices.explanation: Learning from others is good, but copying won't help you develop your own skills. Focus on doing your best work in your own way!

choices.text: Stop being friends with the person who got an A+
choices.explanation: Being friends with people who do well can actually help us learn! It's better to focus on our own growth rather than comparing!

endingMessage: You're learning an important lesson! Comparing ourselves to others usually makes us feel worse. Your B+ represents your hard work - that's something to be proud of! Focus on your own journey! üìä

title: Not Getting It
story: Octopus tried to explain to their parents why they wanted to join the robotics club, but their parents didn't seem to understand. They kept suggesting other activities instead. Octopus felt frustrated and misunderstood. What should Octopus do?
imagePrompt: An octopus trying to explain something to adult octopuses, looking frustrated

choices.text: Write down reasons why robotics matters to them, find examples of how it helps learning, and have a calm conversation with parents
choices.explanation: Excellent communication strategy! Sometimes parents need to understand why something matters to us. Preparing your thoughts and having a calm conversation helps!

choices.text: Get angry and storm off
choices.explanation: Getting angry usually makes communication harder. It's better to take time to calm down and then explain your feelings clearly!

choices.text: Give up and not try to explain
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel frustrated, but giving up means your parents might never understand. Try explaining in a different way!

choices.text: Join robotics without telling parents
choices.explanation: Going behind parents' backs usually causes bigger problems. It's better to work on communication and understanding each other!

endingMessage: You showed great communication skills! Feeling misunderstood is frustrating, but finding ways to express yourself clearly helps others understand what matters to you. Keep trying! ü§ñ

title: Waiting My Turn
story: Elephant was waiting in line for the slide at the playground. Other animals kept cutting in front. Elephant had been waiting a long time and felt impatient. They wanted to push ahead too. What should Elephant do?
imagePrompt: An elephant waiting patiently in a line at the playground, looking a bit frustrated

choices.text: Wait patiently, ask a grown-up for help if needed, and remember that waiting is part of playing fairly
choices.explanation: Great patience! Waiting our turn shows respect for others and helps everyone have fun. If someone cuts, asking a grown-up for help is okay!

choices.text: Push ahead of everyone else
choices.explanation: Pushing ahead might make others feel sad or angry. Waiting our turn helps everyone have fun and feel fair!

choices.text: Leave and play something else
choices.explanation: It's okay to play something else if waiting feels too hard, but learning to wait our turn is an important skill!

choices.text: Yell at the other animals
choices.explanation: Yelling usually makes things worse. It's better to wait patiently or ask a grown-up for help if someone isn't being fair!

endingMessage: You showed wonderful patience! Waiting our turn can be hard, but it helps everyone have fun together. Being patient is a superpower! ‚è∞

title: Big Feelings
story: Tiger's tower of blocks fell down right before they finished building it. Tiger felt very angry and wanted to throw the blocks and scream. What should Tiger do?
imagePrompt: A tiger looking angry next to fallen blocks, feeling frustrated

choices.text: Take deep breaths, count to five, and then try building again
choices.explanation: Excellent! Taking deep breaths helps our bodies calm down when we feel angry. Then we can try again with a clear mind!

choices.text: Throw the blocks and scream
choices.explanation: Throwing things can hurt others or break things. It's better to use our words or take deep breaths to calm down!

choices.text: Cry and give up
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel sad when things don't work out, but taking a break and trying again can help us feel better!

choices.text: Blame someone else for the blocks falling
choices.explanation: Sometimes things just happen! It's better to focus on how we can handle our feelings and try again!

endingMessage: You handled those big feelings so well! Feeling angry is normal, and you found healthy ways to calm down. That's a superpower! üí™

title: Too Loud!
story: Mouse was at a birthday party with lots of kids running around, music playing, and everyone talking loudly. Mouse felt overwhelmed by all the noise and wanted to hide. What should Mouse do?
imagePrompt: A small mouse looking overwhelmed at a noisy birthday party

choices.text: Find a quiet corner to take a break, ask a grown-up for help, or step outside for fresh air
choices.explanation: Perfect! It's okay to need quiet time. Finding a calm space or asking for help shows you know how to take care of yourself!

choices.text: Start crying and run away
choices.explanation: Running away might make you feel more scared. It's better to find a quiet spot or ask a grown-up for help!

choices.text: Try to ignore it and stay in the loud room
choices.explanation: It's okay to try, but if the noise feels too much, it's perfectly fine to take a break! Taking care of ourselves is important!

choices.text: Yell at everyone to be quiet
choices.explanation: Yelling might make things louder! It's better to find a quiet space or ask a grown-up for help!

endingMessage: You listened to your body! When things feel too loud or overwhelming, taking a break is a smart choice. You're learning to take care of yourself! üéà

title: Not Winning
story: Frog was playing a game with friends and kept losing. Every time they didn't win, Frog felt upset and wanted to quit playing. What should Frog do?
imagePrompt: A frog looking upset after losing a game, with friends nearby

choices.text: Remember that games are for fun, congratulate the winner, and keep playing
choices.explanation: Wonderful attitude! Games are about having fun together, not just winning. Being a good sport makes everyone happy!

choices.text: Quit the game and go home
choices.explanation: Quitting might make you miss out on fun! Remember, games are about playing together, not just winning!

choices.text: Keep playing but feel grumpy
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel a little upset, but trying to have fun even when we don't win helps us enjoy the game more!

choices.text: Change the rules so they can win
choices.explanation: Changing rules isn't fair to others. It's better to remember that playing together is what makes games fun!

endingMessage: You're learning to be a great sport! Winning is fun, but playing together and having fun is even more important. You're a wonderful friend! üéÆ

title: Group Work Worries
story: Deer was put in a group for a school project, but the other group members weren't doing their part. Deer felt stressed because they were doing all the work and worried about getting a bad grade. What should Deer do?
imagePrompt: A deer looking stressed, surrounded by group project materials while other animals aren't helping

choices.text: Talk to the teacher about the situation, try to divide tasks clearly with group members, and ask for help if needed
choices.explanation: Excellent problem-solving! Talking to the teacher and trying to work together fairly is the right approach. You don't have to handle it alone!

choices.text: Do all the work alone without saying anything
choices.explanation: Doing everything alone isn't fair to you and doesn't help your group learn to work together. It's okay to ask for help!

choices.text: Get angry and refuse to work with the group
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel frustrated, but getting angry usually makes things harder. Talking about the problem usually works better!

choices.text: Blame the group members to the teacher
choices.explanation: It's better to focus on solving the problem together rather than blaming. Talking to the teacher about finding solutions helps everyone!

endingMessage: You handled that challenge well! Group work can be tricky, but learning to communicate and ask for help is an important skill. You're growing! üìã

title: Words That Hurt
story: Hedgehog's classmates were making fun of their new haircut. They kept laughing and saying mean things. Hedgehog felt hurt and embarrassed. What should Hedgehog do?
imagePrompt: A hedgehog looking sad while other animals laugh nearby

choices.text: Tell a teacher or trusted adult, remember that mean words say more about the speaker than you, and spend time with kind friends
choices.explanation: Perfect response! Telling an adult and remembering that you're wonderful just as you are is the right way to handle this. Mean words don't define you!

choices.text: Say mean things back
choices.explanation: Saying mean things back usually makes things worse. It's better to tell an adult and remember that you're awesome just as you are!

choices.text: Pretend it doesn't bother them
choices.explanation: It's okay to try to ignore it, but if mean words hurt, it's important to tell someone. You don't have to handle it alone!

choices.text: Change their appearance to fit in
choices.explanation: You shouldn't have to change who you are! Being yourself is what makes you special. It's better to tell an adult about the teasing!

endingMessage: You're strong and wonderful just as you are! Mean words say more about the people saying them than about you. Remember, you're amazing! üí™

title: Busy as a Bee
story: Bee was signed up for soccer, piano lessons, art class, and swimming - all in one week! Bee felt exhausted and didn't have time to just play or relax. What should Bee do?
imagePrompt: A tired bee surrounded by sports equipment, musical instruments, and art supplies

choices.text: Talk to parents about feeling overwhelmed, choose favorite activities, and make sure there's time for rest and play
choices.explanation: Great self-awareness! It's important to have balance. Talking about how you feel and choosing what you love most helps you enjoy activities more!

choices.text: Keep doing everything even though they're exhausted
choices.explanation: Being exhausted all the time isn't healthy! It's okay to slow down and choose what you really love. Rest is important too!

choices.text: Feel guilty about wanting to quit something
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel a little guilty, but it's okay to choose what you love! Having time to rest and play is important for growing kids!

choices.text: Quit everything without talking to anyone
choices.explanation: Talking about your feelings first is better than quitting everything! You might find a balance that works for everyone!

endingMessage: You're learning about balance! Having fun activities is great, but rest and free play time are important too. You're doing great! ‚öñÔ∏è

title: Oops, I Made a Mistake
story: Monkey accidentally broke a friend's favorite pencil during art class. The friend looked upset, and Monkey felt embarrassed and didn't know what to say. What should Monkey do?
imagePrompt: A monkey looking embarrassed, holding a broken pencil while a friend looks sad

choices.text: Apologize sincerely, offer to replace it or help fix it, and learn to be more careful
choices.explanation: Perfect! Saying sorry and trying to make it right shows you care. Everyone makes mistakes - what matters is how we handle them!

choices.text: Pretend it wasn't them
choices.explanation: Pretending won't make things better and might hurt the friendship. It's better to be honest and apologize!

choices.text: Feel too embarrassed to say anything
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel embarrassed, but saying sorry helps fix things. Your friend will probably understand - accidents happen!

choices.text: Blame someone else
choices.explanation: Blaming others isn't fair and won't help. Taking responsibility and apologizing is the right thing to do!

endingMessage: You showed great character! Making mistakes is part of learning, and you handled it the right way. That's what good friends do! ‚úèÔ∏è

title: Online World
story: Flamingo's friends were all on a social media app, but Flamingo's parents said they weren't old enough yet. Flamingo felt left out and pressured to join secretly. What should Flamingo do?
imagePrompt: A flamingo looking at a phone while friends are using social media, feeling left out

choices.text: Talk to parents about feelings, find other ways to connect with friends, and respect the family rules
choices.explanation: Excellent decision! Talking about your feelings and finding other ways to connect shows maturity. Family rules are there to keep you safe!

choices.text: Join secretly without telling parents
choices.explanation: Going behind parents' backs breaks trust and can be unsafe. It's better to talk about your feelings and find solutions together!

choices.text: Feel angry and resentful toward parents
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel frustrated, but talking about it helps. Your parents want to keep you safe - maybe you can find a compromise!

choices.text: Stop being friends with people who use the app
choices.explanation: You don't have to stop being friends! There are lots of ways to connect with friends that don't involve social media!

endingMessage: You showed great maturity! Respecting family rules while finding ways to connect with friends shows you're growing up responsibly. You're doing great! üì±

title: Changing Body
story: Caterpillar noticed their body was changing - growing taller, voice changing, and feeling different. They felt self-conscious and worried about what others thought. What should Caterpillar do?
imagePrompt: A caterpillar looking at their reflection, feeling self-conscious about changes

choices.text: Remember that body changes are normal, talk to trusted adults about questions, and focus on being healthy and happy
choices.explanation: Perfect! Body changes are a normal part of growing up. Everyone goes through it, and talking to trusted adults helps us understand what's happening!

choices.text: Try to hide or change their body
choices.explanation: Our bodies are changing naturally, and that's okay! Trying to change or hide our bodies isn't healthy. Everyone goes through this!

choices.text: Worry constantly about what others think
choices.explanation: It's normal to feel self-conscious, but remember - everyone your age is going through changes too! You're not alone!

choices.text: Avoid looking in mirrors completely
choices.explanation: Avoiding our reflection won't make the changes go away. It's better to learn that these changes are normal and part of growing up!

endingMessage: You're growing up beautifully! Body changes are a normal part of becoming a teenager. Everyone goes through this - you're not alone! Remember, you're amazing just as you are! üå±

title: High Expectations
story: Hawk's parents and teachers kept talking about getting good grades for middle school and high school. Hawk felt pressured to be perfect and worried about disappointing everyone. What should Hawk do?
imagePrompt: A hawk surrounded by books and report cards, looking stressed about expectations

choices.text: Talk to parents and teachers about feeling pressured, focus on doing their best rather than being perfect, and remember that mistakes help us learn
choices.explanation: Excellent! Talking about pressure and focusing on doing your best (not being perfect) is healthy. Learning from mistakes is part of growing!

choices.text: Try to be perfect at everything
choices.explanation: Trying to be perfect usually leads to stress and burnout. It's better to do your best and learn from mistakes - that's how we grow!

choices.text: Feel stressed but not say anything
choices.explanation: It's okay to feel stressed, but talking about it helps! Adults want to support you, not pressure you. Let them know how you feel!

choices.text: Give up on schoolwork completely
choices.explanation: Giving up won't help! It's better to talk about the pressure and find a balance between doing well and taking care of yourself!

endingMessage: You're learning important life skills! Doing your best is what matters, not being perfect. Talking about pressure helps adults support you better. You've got this! üìö

title: Disagreement with Friend
story: Raccoon and their best friend had a big disagreement about something important. Both felt strongly about their side, and neither wanted to back down. Raccoon felt conflicted - they didn't want to lose the friendship. What should Raccoon do?
imagePrompt: Two raccoons having a disagreement, both looking upset

choices.text: Take a break to cool down, listen to the friend's perspective, share their own feelings calmly, and try to find a solution together
choices.explanation: Perfect approach! Taking time to cool down and then listening to each other helps resolve conflicts. Good friendships can handle disagreements!

choices.text: Refuse to talk to the friend ever again
choices.explanation: Ending a friendship over one disagreement usually makes us feel worse. It's better to try to work through conflicts together!

choices.text: Give in completely just to keep the friendship
choices.explanation: It's okay to compromise, but giving in completely isn't healthy. Good friendships allow both people to share their feelings!

choices.text: Get other friends to take their side
choices.explanation: Getting others involved usually makes conflicts bigger. It's better to work things out directly with your friend!

endingMessage: You showed great maturity! Disagreements happen in even the best friendships. Learning to communicate and work through conflicts is an important skill. You're growing! üí¨
